column1: In Trump v. Hawaii, will the Supreme Court rule on whether the September 2017 Presidential Proclamation on immigration violates or likely violates the Establishment Clause of the Constitution?
column4: Yes, and will rule that it does not
column5: ['Yes, and will rule that it does', 'Yes, and will rule that it does not', 'No']
column6: ['US Policy']
column11: In September 2017, President Trump issued a Proclamation that put substantial limitations on the entry of citizens from six Muslim-majority countries (The White House). A District Court granted a preliminary injunction preventing enforcement of a large part of the Proclamation, and the Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit affirmed, for the most part, the District Court's injunction (SCOTUS Blog). President Trump appealed (SCOTUS Blog). "Likely violates" refers to a situation in which the Court makes a decision on the Establishment Clause for the purposes of ruling on the preliminary injunction, but does not make a direct ruling on the proclamation. The Supreme Court is expected to hand down its decision in its current term, but if it does not, the question will resolve as No. See our FAQ to learn about how we resolve questions and how scores are calculated.

Presidential power in foreign affairs is virtually unlimited
https://legaldictionary.net/concurring-opinion/

This has always been a very difficult question in my view. If it were simply a question of will SCOTUS support Trump's travel ban or not, it would have been much easier. But this question asks just one thing. Will SCOTUS rule that the travel ban violates the Establishment Clause or not. Initially, I forecast 90% No-- figuring the Court would find one or more aspects of the statutory questions to base its decision and as minimalists, would avoid the Establishment Clause issue. I am not an attorney but researched all four of the questions and came to the conclusion that whether SCOTUS agrees or not with Trump's ban, they would rule on the statutory aspects of it. I figured that by version 3 of the travel ban, they got it right (legally).
I thought about it some more, and this question sure is tricky.
From the Appellate Court decision:
@lsgold7 makes a good case.

The arguments have not touched anything about the Establishment clause. The lawyer representing Hawaii insisted again and again that the proclamation expands executive branch power, stepping on Congress' toes in Immigration and Naturalization Law, a constitutional right reserved to Congress. The DoJ lawyer said that it is within the executive branch power to enforce the INA by banning citizen from countries who did not cooperate to the vetting process. To the point of this question, Justice Alito raised the point that by reading the text of the proclamation alone, one cannot infer that this has anything to do with Muslims. Other Justices, with exception from Justice Sotomayor, did not ask any question to counter Justice Alito. Therefore, I would put the chance for No to 80%. Now I need to figure out if they would put in some language in the Majority opinion pertaining to the First Amendment Establishment clause. Will revise this for sure.
They are not going to address the establishment clause claim. See www.nytimes.com by former Senator Danforth and Governor Kean It violates 3 congressional statutes and separation of powers.

Because this Proclamation actually does violate the constitution, regardless of statistical analysis, and past probabilities or political affiliations. I followed it closely when Trump was first elected, and Hawaii battled in the courts and won. At the end of the day there is no substitute for the truth, forecasting or not. Is this a big risk for my first forecast? Sure. But I believe in truth over statistics, probability and making a decision based on what I think will happen. I am sure I will learn a valuable lesson after this one, but hey... let me learn that lesson on my first forecast out of the gate. @Saarinen raises THE question that I believe is at the heart of the case: whether the case is justiciable. Next issue; does the question of "justiciable" only apply to the 4th question raised in this case by Hawaii? ie. whether the proclamation "likely violates the Establishment Clause" or does the question of "justiciable" also apply to the other 3 questions? My forecast is based on the latter concept.

They are likely to force a stall until after the election. On the other hand, they may have inside information about one of their number retiring and being replace by a Trump Appointee. In that case they may want to get it done while they have four solid anti-Trump votes.

I followed this so-called travel ban litigation intensively during the year 2017. I lost interest late in the year, so this is based on what I remember from the original litigation and a cursory look at this case.
Amicus Briefs overwhelmingly indicate EO-3, Section 2 will persuade a majority of Justices that it violates the Free Exercise Clause of the First Amendment.
The president often comes to snap decisions that are not grounded in law.
Establishment Clause: "Congress shall make no law respecting an establishment of religion, or prohibiting the free exercise thereof."
Bigotry is not coterminous with establishment. There is probably enough lipstick on this pig to gie the Court cover for finding some other issue to talk about.
The court may well play a waiting game on this one.

Because the proclamation had several versions, one of which is likely to be upheld under the broad executive power to act in the interest of national security. That version, being affirmed, will allow the SCOTUS to avoid the larger constitutional question raised in Trump v. Hawaii.
